Executive Summary
1.1    Discussion
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for the chlorine system at the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility located in Holyoke, Massachusetts.  This Plan has been developed in accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 68, A?Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.A?  The purpose of these provisions and this RMP is to prevent the accidental releases of toxic and flammable substances that can cause harm to the public and to the environment.
This RMP was originally developed by the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility consultant, Tighe & Bond, Inc., specifically to prevent and mitigate accidental releases associated with the storage and handling operations at the Holyoke facility.  The RMP provides a summary of the risk management program implemented at the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility and was developed following the Environmental Protection AgencyA?s guidance documents for the regulated chemicals.  The RMP is available to government agencies and the public for review.
Tighe & Bond has performed the requisite review and regulatory update necessary for covered facilities on their five year RMP Submission Anniversary.  This March 4, 2009 review included:
A?    A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the covered process using a methodology involving checklists developed from the EPA RMP Guidance, as well as a physical inspection of the covered process;
A?    Performance of an off site consequence analysis (OCA) taking into account data revised from the year 2000 census; and
A?    A general review of operating and maintenance procedures with facility operations and environmental personnel.
The following items provide an overview of the Holyoke Water Treatment FacilityA?s RMP in accordance with 40 CFR 68.155.

1.2    Facility Description and Covered Process
The City of Holyoke B.O.W.C. owns and operates the City of Holyoke Water Treatment Facility.  The purpose of the facility is to generate chlorinated solution, which is used t

o disinfect the Holyoke water supply.  The chlorine is stored in a room equipped with ventilation and chlorine alarms.  The chlorine gas is mixed with water in the chlorinators and is directly injected into the treatment locations.
The City of Holyoke Water Treatment Facility currently stores up to 28,000 pounds of chlorine in fourteen one-ton containers.  Since the City of Holyoke Water Treatment Facility stores more than 2,500 pounds of chlorine, the facility is required to comply with the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.

1.3    Release Scenarios
A worst case release scenario and two alternative release scenarios were performed and documented in the original RMP filing.  These scenarios were re-calculated for the five year anniversary updating population and receptor information.  Based on guidelines provided by the EPA in the 2004 RMP Submit Instruction Manual, release scenario information is not provided in this Executive Summary.

1.4    Administrative and Engineering Controls
The Holyoke Water Treatment Facility has implemented a prevention program (RMP Program 2) to administratively limit the potential for a worst case or alternative release.  No passive measures, however, were taken to minimize the impacts of these releases.  Specific measures employed in this program include safety reviews, hazard reviews, operating procedure reviews, training and maintenance and inspection.  These reviews are conducted, consistent with the operation of the covered process, once (1) every three (3) years in association with the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility Compliance Audit (40 CFR 68.58) or with major changes.  The hazard review is required every five (5) years or with major changes.  Maintenance and inspection is conducted at specific intervals as outlined in the Holyoke Water Treatment FacilityA?s RMP.  The results of the most recent reviews are also maintained at the facility.

1.5    Mitigation Measures
Certain engineering controls are used to mitigate the potential effects

of the alternative release scenarios and are listed in Section 8.4.e of the RMP submittal.

1.6    General Accidental Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Items
The Holyoke Water Treatment Facility has implemented a Prevention Program 2 RMP to prevent the release of toxic substances that can cause harm to the public and the environment.  The Prevention Program 2, in general, consists of the following:
A?    Safety Information (40 CFR 68.48)
A?    Hazard Review (40 CFR 68.50)
A?    Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.52)
A?    Training (40 CFR 68.54)
A?    Maintenance (40 CFR 68.56)
A?    Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.58)
A?    Incident Investigation (40 CFR 68.60)
A?    Emergency Response Program (40 CFR 68.90)
This Prevention Program 2 RMP has been implemented at the facility and the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility maintains a copy onsite that is available for review.

1.7    Five Year Accident History
There have been no releases of chlorine at the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility in the five (5) years preceding the submission of this RMP.

1.8    Emergency Response Program
The Holyoke Water Treatment Facility has coordinated its Emergency Response Program (ERP) with the appropriate agencies as required under 40 CFR 68.90 to include the following activities:
A?    A public meeting and/or notification was made to the general public relative to the chlorine stored at the facility.
A?    The Federal Bureau of Investigation was notified of the meeting date and location.
A?    Appropriate agencies were provided with ERP information including the Holyoke Water Treatment FacilityA?s ERP, offsite consequence analysis, prevention measures, etc.
A?    Tier II reports are submitted to the appropriate agencies on an annual basis to periodically update the facilityA?s emergency response information.

1.9    Safety Improvements
The following list provides a summary of the items implemented at the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility in association with this RMP that are designed to improve safety.
A?    Safety Review (Aud

it every 3 years)
A?    Hazard Review (Audit every 3 years, update every 5 years)
A?    Operating Procedures Review (Audit ever 3 years)
A?    Training (Audit every 3 hears, training once every 3 years at a minimum)
A?    Maintenance and Inspection (conducted annually, audit every 3 years)
A?    Emergency Response Program (coordination with local emergency personnel)
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) update was conducted at the Holyoke Water Treatment Facility on March 4, 2009 and involved operations, management and environmental personnel.  The updated analysis identified some minor recommendations that will be implemented within the next year.
